main_text:
Can a government legitimately prevent consenting adults from
publishing and viewing pornography in private, or would this be an
unjustified violation of basic freedoms?

This question lies at the heart of a debate that raises fundamental
issues about just when, and on what grounds, the state is justified in
using its coercive powers to limit individual freedom.

Traditionally, liberals defended the freedom of consenting adults to
publish and consume pornography in private from moral and religious
conservatives who wanted pornography banned for its (alleged) obscenity
and morally corrupting influence on consumers. In more recent times,
however, the pornography debate has taken on a somewhat new and
surprising shape. Some feminists have found themselves allied with
their traditional conservative foes in calling on the state to regulate
(some) pornography—although the primary focus of feminist concern
is not obscenity, but rather on (alleged) harms to women. And some
liberals have joined pro-censorship feminists in suggesting that the
harms that violent, degrading and misogynistic pornography causes to
women’s social standing and opportunities may be sufficiently great to
justify legal regulation of it. Many others, both liberals and
feminists, remain unconvinced. They are doubtful that pornography is a
significant cause of sexual oppression, or that the “blunt and
treacherous” instrument of the law is the best solution to
pornography’s harms. As we shall see, debates over whether and how
(some) pornography is harmful, and what should be done about harmful
types of pornography, are very much alive (Altman and Watson 2018;
McGowan 2019; Mikkola 2019).
